results.title: What did you do in the Great War Mummy?
results.brief_description: This film shows that there have traditionally been two labour markets in Britain based on the concepts of “mens” work and “women’s work”. Traces the history of women workers in the twentieth century with emphasis on the roles they played during the two world wars. These national emergencies shaped the change in attitudes regarding women and work, and during those conflicts, “a woman’s place” was no longer just in the home.

results.title: What comes out of the blast furnace?
results.creator_credit: John Wiles, Frank A. Hoare and Merton Park
results.brief_description: In addition to iron, the furnace produces slag and gas. The film describes the uses to which all three can be put. Explains that the object of the blast furnace is the smelt iron, but in the process other things are also produced, such as slag which collects in the hearth of the furnace together with the hot metal, and gas, which passes out of the top of the furnace. Shows how these products are treated and the uses to which they are put. Makes the point that very little is allowed to go to waste in a modern iron works.
results.title_for_label: What comes out of the blast furnace?
results.creator_credit_for_label: John Wiles, Frank A. Hoare and Merton Park

Shows how these products are treated and the uses to which they are put. Makes the point that very little is allowed to go to waste in a modern iron works.

results.title: What can I do?
results.creator_credit: Jerry A Callner and Callner Film Productions
results.brief_description: The democratic system of government is a system meant for participation and involvement. Citizens can influence ongoing social change through personal political and social action. The use of the media, the impact of effective letters to the press and local members, and the power of the single vote are all examined.

results.title: What are we doing to our children? Part 2: welfare and the fatherless family
results.brief_description: Looks at the consequences of America’s Welfare system on young children. Daycare centers, unwed or working others, absentee fathers due to the welfare “man in the house” rule combine to inflict trauma on young children.

results.title: What are we doing to our children, locked up, locked out
results.brief_description: A poignant case history of a damaged, unstable family and a child’s resultant antisocial behavioral problems. Issues arising from this case are child advocacy in the courts and the rehabilitative effect of jailing juvenile delinquents. From the series CBS reports.

results.title: What about us
results.brief_description: The film shows a Swedish school class in which the children are all between nine and ten years old. The children give us their view on changes taking place in our environment.

results.title: What about me?: young people and local government
results.creator_credit: Jeff Spencer, Ivan Gaal and TV Ed Productions
results.brief_description: Katie, a Year 12 student wants to find out more about what her Local City Council can do for her. This program follows her inquiries and shows what she discovers.
